captions.text:
When Allrecipes member, Shelly,
submitted this recipe for Banana Bread,

she commented, "Why compromise
the banana flavor? This banana bread

is moist and delicious, with loads
of banana flavor!

Friends and family love my recipe,
and say it's by far the best!

It's wonderfully toasted,
Enjoy!"

Let's start by preheating the
oven to 350 degrees.

Lightly grease a 9 by 5 inch
loaf pan with softened butter,
or vegetable oil spray.

Next, in a large bowl, combine
2 cups all purpose flour,
with a teaspoon of baking soda,
and a quarter teaspoon of salt.

Now, in a separate bowl, cream
together half a cup of butter,

that's been softening at room
temperature,

with 3 quarters of a cup of
brown sugar.
Then beat 2 eggs,
and add those to the mixture.

And now, mash 4 to 5 over ripe
bananas.

In the end you're looking for
2 and a third cups banana.
So use what you need.
Blend it all together well.

Now we can stir the banana
mixture into the flour mixture.

Mix it just to moisten, you don't
want to over work the flour.

And pour the batter into the
prepared loaf pan.

Place the filled pan in a preheated
oven for 60 to 65 minutes.

Until a toothpick inserted in the
center of the loaf comes out clean.

Let the bread cool in the pan
for ten minutes,

and then turn it out onto
a wire rack.

This banana bread is so good that
they named it twice:
Banana Banana Bread!

title: How to Make Banana Banana Bread

comments.author: Mickey girl

comments.text:
How much flour do you have, Mickey girl? You can change the number of 
servings to reduce the amount of flour used. The original recipe makes 12 
servings and 1 9x5 inch loaf. If you want to change the number of servings 
to half this amount, here's how: 
1) Find the recipe link at the top of this page under the "published on" 
date (or
click "Show More" to open the box to find the link). For this banana bread 
recipe it's this link: 
http://allrecipes.com/recipe/banana-banana-bread/detail.aspx

2) Click on the link to open the recipe page, and then under “Ingredients,” 
find the line "Original recipe makes 12 servings" (or 6 cups or whatever 
the finished amount is for each recipe). 

3) Just to the right of this line, click on "Change Servings." A box will 
open where you can type in the number to change the number of servings (the 
original recipe's serving amount will automatically show in the box). 

4) Type in the number of servings you want, and then click the box to the 
right that says “Adjust recipe.” All the ingredient amounts will 
immediately change to amounts needed—more or less—for the new number of 
servings.

comments.author: Enoch Cheng

comments.text: Hi, why my banana bread did not rise﻿
comments.author: shua32 shua32

comments.text:
Sorry to hear this, shua32 shua32. That's disappointing. There are many 
variables when baking so it's difficult to know exactly what is causing the 
problem. Here are some things to check:1 - Did your oven get hot enough? 
You can double-check the temperature by buying a separate thermometer and 
placing it inside to see if its temperature reads the same as the oven 
temperature. 
2 - Was the oven preheated before you put in the bread to cook? 
3 - Were the eggs and bananas at room temperature? They'll mix more easily 
when room temperature. 
4 - Also, it's important not to over-beat the batter when folding the 
bananas into the flour mixture. Too much beating will take air out of the 
batter and keep it from rising. 
5 - Was everything measured accurately? (Here's a link to the original 
recipe so you may review the ingredients: 
http://allrecipes.com/recipe/banana-banana-bread/detail.aspx)
6 - What size are the bananas? If they're too large, they can add more 
moisture to the batter and make it harder to rise.
We hope you try the recipe again. Let us know if you still have problems.

Terrific question, joe cruz! Over-beating the batter will remove the air 
that helps the bread rise. Too much beating also compressed the eggs that 
give baked goods steam needed for leavening. Hope this helps.

comments.text:
I am really annoyed with this recipe. I did everything as described 
step-by-step and my banana bread turned out very dense in texture. It was 
far too overdone on the outside and under-cooked inside, even though I 
allowed it to remain in the oven for longer than the recipe called for 
because the inside was simply not cooking. I wasted my time and ingredients 
unfortunately!﻿
comments.author: S Billy

comments.text:
We feel your distress, S Billy! It's so disappointing and frustrating for 
something you've worked hard to make--and looked forward to eating--fail. 
Bummer! Baking is tricky. It's hard to know exactly what went wrong and 
make a diagnosis, but a guess about what's happening would focus on the 
oven--not anything you did or the recipe. It sounds like the oven's 
temperature is off. This isn't unusual. Maybe you've noticed it before with 
other things? The best way to check the oven temperature is to buy a small 
oven thermometer you can set inside the oven to check the actual 
temperature against the oven's setting. If there's a difference, you can 
usually recalibrate the oven temperature following instructions in the 
owner's manual. Or you may manually turn the oven down to accommodate the 
difference. Does your oven have two heat sources? It's possible one is not 
working, which means all the heat is overcooking the top of the loaf. If 
you can share anything else about what you noticed, please let us know and 
we'll offer more ideas.
comments.author: Allrecipes

comments.text: Can i use baking powder instead of baking soda??﻿
comments.author: Shar Eusebio

comments.text:
You can, Shar Eisebio, with some changes. To use baking powder instead of 
baking soda, you need to use 3 times more baking powder. For example, 
because this recipe calls for 1 teaspoon of baking soda, you will need to 
add 3 teaspoons of baking powder. Baking powder will have a slight effect 
on the taste of what you are making, but it won’t be significant.

comments.text: What is the substitute for egg I'm this bread﻿
comments.author: Suman jain paras jain

comments.text:
Thanks for your question, Suman jain paras jain. Eggs act as a leavener in 
baked goods, holding ingredients together and helping the cake rise. This 
means an egg substitute must be a good one. Finely ground flax seeds and 
mashed bananas may be used, or pureed tofu (use 1/4 cup of pureed tofu for 
1 egg). You might also use a prepared (commercial) egg replacement. To find 
this, look in the egg section of your grocery store.

comments.author: Allrecipes

comments.text:
What if I replace butter with margarine? Will there be a difference in 
taste? Or?﻿
comments.author: Katrina W

comments.text:
Great question! Butter, shortening, and margarine are all types of fats. 
It’s the type of fat they contain that you need to consider when choosing 
the one that’s best for whatever you are baking or cooking.  Butter comes 
from an animal source, so therefore contains cholesterol and saturated fat. 
It is great for baking, as it adds nice flavor and great texture for 
cookies and pastries. Margarines vary a lot in the types of oils used, so 
you need to look at the labels. Those that contain higher amounts of fats 
are best for baking, as those with less fat will contain more water and 
will cause tougher baked products. Flavor varies with margarines too, so 
you need to find one that you like. Hope that helps - Happy Cooking!

comments.author: Benaziraeiou Channar

comments.text:
Hi,
I was wondering, why do You need to mix the ingredients in separate bowls?  
Wouldn't it be easier to just mix the eggs first, then add sugar and butter 
and at the end flour and baking soda. The only separate bowl would be maybe 
for mashing the bananas.﻿
comments.author: PaulaLionHeart

comments.text:
+Allrecipes Youtube Thank you very much for that kind response. I have 
tried this recipe several times and everyone loved it!
comments.author: PaulaLionHeart

comments.text:
Hi Paula, great question! By mixing the dry ingredients separately and 
whisking them a bit before adding them to liquid, you are making sure that 
the baking soda & sugar get evenly distributed throughout the flour. Also, 
the flour will then be able to absorb liquid easier and more uniformly 
without the dough becoming over-worked. You want to get it all mixed as 
much as possible before you get the flour wet, so that as soon as the flour 
gets wet, you're doing the least possible mixing to incorporate the 
ingredients. Hope that helps - Happy Cooking!
comments.author: Allrecipes Youtube

You bet, tim bautista! Use either and 8"x8" or 9"x9" square pan. You'll 
have enough batter for either. because the batter will be spread out more 
in the square pan, check for doneness after 45 minutes baking time. The 
bread will cook faster than in a loaf pan.

going to remain soggy when it's baked. Measuring exact ingredients is 
important when baking. The batter is always going to taste "floury" before 
it's baked. How large were the bananas? If they were small, you might be 
OK.

comments.text:
What is all purpose flour?? I assume it's wheat flour, but that's a strange 
name?﻿
comments.author: Quarkwano

comments.text:
You've got it right, freakish70. In the States, we call it "all-purpose 
flour," while in many other kitchens of the world, it's known as "plain 
flour." If you want to get technical, it's flour is made from a blend of 
high-gluten hard wheat and low-gluten soft wheat. It’s fine-textured flour 
milled from the inner part of the wheat kernel and contains neither the 
germ (the sprouting part) nor the bran (the outer coating). Very versatile!
comments.author: Allrecipes

comments.text: Its also known as plain flour...

comments.author: Quarkwano

comments.text:
+Quarkwano
There's nothing at all odd about that.. First off, "regular flour" isn't an 
"American" term - all purpose flour is.... Just like the video said. 
Second, typically when people talk about flour - at least in the United 
States - unless they're specifying they almost always mean wheat flour. 
There is nothing odd about this, in any English speaking countries.... In 
the United Kingdom they call "all purpose" flour "plain" flour - once again 
without specifying as to whether it was wheat or not. So go take your 
American dissing somewhere else...

comments.text: How do I cut this recipe in half﻿
comments.author: Laila Hashem

comments.text:
It's easy, Laila Hashem. Here's how:
1) Open the recipe page (Here's the link: 
http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Banana-Banana-Bread/Detail.aspx) and find the 
line "Original recipe makes 1 loaf."
2) Just to the right of this line, click on "Change Servings." This will 
open a new line with a box to change the number of servings (the recipe's 
original amount automatically shows in the box; for this recipe it's "12 
servings").
3) Type in the number of servings you want to make (6).
4)  Click on “Adjust Recipe” in the box just to the right. All the 
ingredient amounts will immediately change to the new serving size.
Happy baking!

comments.author: Andrea Zipa

comments.text:
Hi,i just baked my banana bread,for 65 mins,,followed everything 
exactly....but my entire bread is like wet,i mean not raw,but kind of 
raw/wet,i donno exactly what word to describe...but im doubtful if its not 
done,or is it done?is it called extra extra moist?please waiting for a 
reply,just cant wait to eat,smells good though.﻿
comments.author: appu apps

comments.text:
Thx for the quick response.....must get a thermometer to double check the 
oven temp.Thx for d advice....yup,the texture is kinda creamy,i mean if I 
just take a piece of bread n rub it between my fingers,its creamy......its 
not like bready....shud I leave it in the oven for some more time?cos I 
have already cut 2 or 3 slice,which actually weren't completely 
slices.....But thx a ton for the advice,will get a thermometer.Love ur 
other recipes
comments.author: appu apps

comments.text:
That's not good, appu apps. So sorry to hear the news. Were you able to cut 
a slice of the bread? It sounds like the oven may have a temperature 
problem. Do you have a separate thermometer you can put into the oven to 
double-check its setting? Were all the ingredients measured properly? This 
bread is quite moist, but "wet" doesn't sound right.
comments.author: Allrecipes

comments.text:
Baked banana bread using this recipe for 3 times already and I gotta say 
this recipe is the BEST ONE!! It tastes soooooo good. Thanks, Allrecipes!﻿
comments.author: AnnaLiMusic

comments.text:
Hey, AnnaLiMusic, we're thrilled to hear you liked this banana bread 
recipe! You have very good taste!

comments.author: eman tareq

comments.text: what can I substitute for a aluminum pan﻿
comments.author: Kajaun Pugh

comments.text: Thanks
comments.author: Kajaun Pugh

comments.text:
How about a 9-inch x 5-inch ceramic or glass loaf pan, Kajaun Pugh? Or if a 
loaf pan isn't available, you could use a 7-inch round cake pan or even a 
small Bundt cake pan. Some cookware stores sell decorative disposable paper 
loaf pans so you might also try one of those.
comments.author: Allrecipes
